description.narrative: New/additional funds to address COVID-19 The proposed project will support the different local government institute of Government of Bangladesh to improve environmental health and resilience of WASH-deprived urban poor living in slums and low income settlements. To achieve this goal, the expected outcomes of the project are: • WASH deprivation reduced among target communities through increased WASH awareness and access to climate/disaster resilient, community-based WASH services • Local governance in pro-poor WASH service delivery and coordination with other services in target cities and towns improved • WASH policies and strategies improved in favour of urban poor through evidence and advocacy

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Den växande befolkningen boende i slumområden som följd av framförallt den snabba urbaniseringstakten i Bangladesh, har idag en mycket begränsad tillgång till kvalitetssäkrad vatten- och sanitet. Avsaknaden av statlig vatten-, sanitet- och hygienreglering kombinerat med svaga leverantörer inom sektorn ökar bland annat befolkningens sårbarhet mot vattenburna sjukdomar och andra miljörelaterade risker kopplade till katastrofer och översvämningar. Bristerna inom vatten och sanitet har också en stor negativ inverkan på nutrition, hälsa och utbildning. Dessa specifika utmaningar som drabbar den fattiga befolkningen i urbana slumområden kräver lösningar på individ-, kommunal-, institutionell- och politisk nivå. WaterAids föreslagna insatser för att förbättra tillgängligheten till vatten och sanitet i vanligtvis försummade slumområden ligger i linje med övergripande mål i den svenska regeringens strategi att skapa förutsättningar för bättre levnadsvillkor för människor som lever i fattigdom och under förtryck. Insatsen tar en integrerad, tvärsektoriell ansats och kan genom detta bidra till synergier mellan Sidas resultatområden inom resultatstrategin för Bangladesh 2014-2020: i) demokrati, jämställdhet och mänskliga rättigheter, ii) bättre möjligheter för människor som lever i fattigdom iii) bättre miljö, begränsad klimatpåverkan och ökad motståndskraft och iv) förbättrad grundläggande hälsa. Både resultatstrategin och Sidas policyram för svenskt utvecklingssamarbete och humanitärt bistånd understryker vikten av tillgången till hållbara och resilienta vatten- och sanitetsinrättningar i dess betydelse för att förbättra grundläggande hälsa, särskilt mödra-l och barnhälsa, vilket är bevisat betydligt sämre i slumområden jämfört med icke-slumområden. Insatsens arbete med att förbättra vatten och sanitet hos vårdinrättningar samt att ge utbildning till primärhälso- och sjukvårdspersonal bedöms också bidra till att stärka vårdsystemen generellt. Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att fokusera på att på kommunal nivå hjälpa regeringen i Bangladesh och olika lokala myndigheter att förbättra miljö, hälsa och resiliens genom förbättrad vatten- och sanitet hos befolkning boende i slumområden låginkomstområden. För att uppnå detta mål är de förväntade resultaten av projektet: • Vatten- och santitetsbrister minskas bland målgrupper genom ökad vatten- och sanitetsmedvetenhet samt genom ökad tillgång till klimat- och katastrofresilienta samhällstjänster kopplade till vatten- och sanitet; • Lokal förvaltning vid leverans och styrning av vatten- och sanitet, vilket även samordnas med andra samhällstjänster i städer ska och har förbättrats med avseende på vatten och sanitet; • Strategier kopplade till vatten och sanitet skall förbättras till förmån för de fattiga i städerna genom evidensbaserat arbete kombinerat med juridiska medel. Sverige bidrar med 55 MSEK av insatsens totala budget på ca. 67 MSEK under perioden 2018-2022. Insatsen beräknas nå och gynna 450 000 innvånare boende i 170 olika slumområden i Dhaka, Chittagong och Khulna tillsammans med ytterligare tre städer i andra delar av landet.

The projects overarching goal is to improved environmental health and resilience of WASH-deprived urban poor living in slums and low income settlements.
To achieve this goal, the expected outcomes of the project are:
Outcome-1: WASH deprivation reduced among target communities through increased WASH awareness and access to climate resilient WASH services
Outcome-2: Local governance in pro-poor WASH service delivery and coordination with other services in target cities and towns improved
Outcome-3: WASH policies and strategies improved in favour of urban poor through evidence and advocacy

description.narrative:
This conclusion on performance has been developed at the end of the third year (January to December 2020) of five-year contribution WASH for Urban Poor with WaterAid. The project aim is to improve environmental health and resilience of WASH deprived urban poor living in slums and low-income settlements in 3 big cities including Dhaka, Chattogram and Khulna and 3 municipal towns of Sakhipur, Saidpur and Paikgachha. The project is now in its third year and WaterAid Bangladesh with its implementing partners are working to achieve the planned targets in the three major areas reduce WASH deprivation, system strengthening for pro-poor WASH services and updated WASH policies and strategies.
A total of 26,117 people (59 percent female) received access to clean water during this reporting period, and 31,914 people (54 percent female) were reached with improved sanitation services in the project areas consisting of low-income communities, educational institutes, and pavement dweller centers.
To ensure the long-term sustainability of WASH facilities, a total of 350 caretakers have been trained on the operation, maintenance, and management of the WASH facilities. Apart from that, the project has generated a WASH fund in which the community and the institutions have deposited around 10-20% of the total installation/construction cost of the WASH facilities, based on their capability. Over the reporting period, BDT 3.8 million has been mobilized as local WASH fund to be used in the coming years for the O&M of the WASH facilities.
Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, hygiene has been given a special importance during the reported year. During this reporting period, 38,446 people (60 percent female) were directly reached with handwashing messages at communities and institutions. A total of 25,764 women and adolescent girls received awareness messages on MHM through different events and one to one counselling with informative printed materials, and 18,778 people received messages on water safety plan. In addition, 886 hand-washing facilities have been installed at households and institutions by motivation and project fund, which has enabled 69,205 people having access to improved hand-washing habits. To remain consistent with the directives from the government of Bangladesh, the project supported 77 education institutes for the installation of group handwashing devices at the entry point as part of the post-COVID school preparedness. In addition, awareness-raising activities based on COVID-19 were also planned for this year.
Furthermore, the project continues to assist pavement dwellers and city commuters with improved WASH services. Operation and maintenance support to 30 public toilets recorded 2.63 million uses during the reporting period.
During the 2nd year, this project has funded the construction of faecal sludge management (FSM) plants in Saidpur municipalities. Apart from this, the scaling up of another FSM plant in Shakhipur has also been undertaken. During this reporting period, a total number of 1,085 latrine pits/septic tanks were emptied and treated duly, following the health and safety policy of WaterAid. 347 waste bins were distributed to the households of the three municipalities and 06-wheel operated vans for improved Solid Waste Management (SWM) systems among 22,422 people. A total number of 1,938 households were motivated for safe treatment and disposal of child faeces.
As a part of sector capacity building initiatives, international training on faecal sludge and septage management, learning visits, meetings and workshops have been organized for different duty bearers and other stakeholders including project implementing partners. In addition, the project collaborated with multi-sectors such as education, health, and agriculture through 85 meetings and 3 workshops to ensure city wide sustainable WASH services.
As a key WASH player in Bangladesh, pre and post online budget advocacy conference have been organised for influencing government to fill up the financial gap in WASH sector to achieve SDG6 and particularly, address COVID-19 situation.
WaterAid has been engaged at national level to raise awareness among relevant authorities on improved urban WASH policies and strategies, including water efficiency, progressive tariffs, allocation of LIC services and urban rainwater harvesting through sector capacity building and mass campaigning.
The project in collaboration with Dhaka WASA arranged an event to recognize and encourage clients from low-income communities to use the legal connection of public water services and to pay bills on time. Furthermore, in the continuation of advocacy works with WASA, the project personnel regularly engaged in the central and zonal level planning meetings with WASA. During the reporting period, a total of 13 central and zonal coordinating meetings with WASA officials were arranged. As a result, 82 more water points were legalised during the reporting period.
WaterAid Bangladesh is actively involved with Policy Support Branch (PSB) of Local Government Division (LGD) to draft the first National Policy on Public Toilet operation and management in Bangladesh.
A study on water utilities in selected urban municipalities in Bangladesh has been initiated under the project on December 2020. To assess the vulnerability of waste workers during COVID-19 and the effect of the pandemic on MHM of the low-income communities, WAB performed one research during the reporting period on these two themes.
Sector capacity development is another priority area of this project. Accordingly, various conferences, training (Rainwater Harvesting and FSM) and related activities have been performed within the reporting period.
